record.name: Linguistic nativism
record.description: "human infants have at least some linguistically specific innate knowledge." (Pullum & Scholz 2002:10)

record.name: Libertarianism
record.description: Libertarianism accepts that free will is incompatible with determinism, but holds that determinism is false, resolving the Free Will Paradox in a way that preserves free will.

record.name: FEP is not truth-apt because it designates a model structure
record.description: Andrews (2021:1): "I propose that the FEP be reserved to designate a model structure, to which philosophers and scientists add various construals, leading to a plethora of models based on the formal structure of the FEP."

record.name: Pearl blankets vs Friston blankets
record.description:
The original epistemic concept of a Markov blanket (aka 'Pearl blanket') should be distinguished from the ontic concept nowadays employed in active inference (aka 'Friston blanket').


Bruineberg et al 2020:20: "what was once an abstract mathematical construct used to describe conditional independence in graphical models came to be seen as a physical entity that somehow causes conditional independence. This latter interpretation has potentially interesting philosophical implications, but does not follow straightforwardly from the former mathematical construct."

record.name: Generalizations are affected by the structure of the hypothesis space
Linguistic Realism
record.description:
Natural languages are abstract objects, as opposed to concrete psychological or acoustic ones.

  • 1991: https://www.jstor.org/stable/25001444?seq=1#metadata_info_tab_contents
  • 1995: http://cogprints.org/256/1/realism.htm
  • 2018: https://benjamins.com/catalog/slcs.196

record.name: Generalized Darwinism
record.description: Hodgson & Knudsen 2006:2: "ongoing change in [a broad class of] systems is inevitably Darwinian in the sense that it must involve Darwin’s central principles of variation, inheritance and selection."

record.name: Chunking constrains the evolution of linguistic structure
record.description: Isbilen & Christiansen 2020:716: "a significant constraint on the evolution of linguistic structure stems from online chunking processes that enable the construction of multilevel representations of incoming input in real time."

record.name: The success pattern condition is a necessary condition on intentionality
record.larger_position: Dual proposal: success pattern and constancy mechanism
record.description:
de Souza Filho 2022:1: "a state represents a given external feature provided that there is a success pattern present in the behavioural output, and the system uses this state as a proxy for the presence of this external feature."


de Souza Filho 2022:7 cites the following authors as holding this position: Ramsey 1990, White 1990, Millikan 2004, Papineau 1993, Papineau 2017.

record.name: The constancy mechanism condition is a necessary condition on intentionality
record.larger_position: Dual proposal: success pattern and constancy mechanism
record.description:
de Souza Filho 2022:1: "a state is representational provided that the system employs a constancy mechanism in its production."


de Souza Filho 2022:11: "Constancy mechanism condition. A sensory state represents an external feature provided that the sensory system employs a constancy mechanism in its production, such that the production of the state remains constant when the external feature obtains, despite the variety of proximal stimuli reaching the system's sensory apparatus."

record.name: Binarism: beliefs are either real or not real
record.description: This is really a kind of meta-position; it doesn't sit logically equivalent to its siblings within this debate, rather it determines which positions can coexist in the debate.

record.name: Metaphysical vs scientific approach to abstract objects
record.description:
Dennett 1991:28: "The question of whether abstract objects are real -- the question of whether or not "one should be a realist about them" -- can take two different paths, which we might call the metaphysical and the scientific."


Metaphysical: "The metaphysical path simply concerns the reality or existence of abstract objects generally, and does not distinguish them in terms of their scientific utility." (Dennett 1991:28) Examples: centre of population of United States; Dennett's Lost Sock Centre.


Scientific: "[Objects are real when] they are (somehow) good abstract objects. They deserve to be taken seriously, learned about, used. If we go so far as to distinguish them as real (contrasting them, perhaps, with those abstract objects which are bogus), that is because we think they serve in perspicuous representations of real forces, "natural" properties, and the like." (Dennett 1991:29)

record.name: Pro-scientific approach
record.larger_position: Metaphysical vs scientific approach to abstract objects
record.description:
We should be more interested in the scientific approach.


Dennett 1991:28: "[we should be] more interested in the scientific path to realism".

record.name: Mild realism: Beliefs are abstract objects
record.description:
Dennett 1991:29: "I have claimed that beliefs are best considered to be abstract objects rather like centres of gravity."


Dennett 1991:30 attributes this position to himself.

record.name: Mild realism
record.description:
Dennett 1991:29: "My aim on this occasion is not so much to prove that my intermediate doctrine about the reality of psychologcal states is right, but just that it is quite possibly right, because a parallel doctrine is demonstrably right about some simpler cases."


Dennett 1991:32: "...in the root case a pattern is "by definition" a candidate for pattern recognition."


Dennett 1991:34: "A pattern exists in some data -- is real -- if there is a description of the data that is more efficient than the bit map, whether or not anyone can concoct it."

record.name: Industrial-strength Realism
record.description: Dennett 1991:30 attributes this position to Fodor.

record.name: Regular strength realism
record.description: Dennett 1991:30 attributes this position to Davidson.

record.name: Milder-than-mild irrealism
record.description: Dennett 1991:30 attributes this position to Rorty, in which "the pattern is only in the eyes of the beholders".

record.name: Eliminative materialism
record.description: Dennett 1991:30 attributes this position to Paul Churchland.

record.name: Interventionism
record.description:
Causal explanation is distinguished by its relevance for potential interventions


Woodward: Causal explanation provides information about potential manipulations.


McElreath: to know a cause is to be able to predict the outcome of an intervention

record.name: i-theories
record.description: Interventionist theories that take the concepts of intervention and cause to be interdefined.

record.name: p-theories
record.description: Interventionist theories that take the concept of an intervention to be derivative on the concept of a cause, which is primitive.

record.name: Program account
record.description: Jackson & Pettit 1990:108: "the realization of a property may program for the occurrence of an effect without actually contributing to its production."

record.name: Signalhood requires causation
record.description:
Newton 1993 cited by Woodward 2003:26:

What constitutes a signal? It is clear from our arguments above that a signal from A to B is anything that can activate a switch at B on command from A. This would necessarily include any transmission of energy or of information. However, there are some motions that are not of that nature. For example, if you hold your finger in front of a light bulb and observe the shadow cast on a distant screen, the speed of the shadow, as you move your finger, is proportional to the distance to the screen. If that distance is large enough, in principle the shadow can move as fast as you please. However, as it rushes from a point A to a point B, both on the screen, it cannot be used to activate a switch at B on command from A. Therefore, a superluminal speed of such a shadow would not violate the relativity-causality based prohibition. There are many other speeds of phenomena in physics that are also free from this limitation.

record.name: Manipulability theory
record.description:
Woodward 2003:59:

(M) A necessary and sufficient condition for X to be a (type-level) direct cause of Y with respect to a variable set V is that there be a possible intervention on X that will change Y or the probability distribution of Y when one holds fixed at some value all other variables Zi in V. A necessary and sufficient condition for X to be a (type-level) contributing cause of Y with respect to variable set V is that (i) there be a directed path from X to Y such that each link in this path is a direct causal relationship: that is, a set of variables Z1 . . . Zn such that X is a direct cause of Z1, which is in turn a direct cause of Z2, which is a direct cause of . . . Zn, which is a direct cause of Y, and that (ii) there be some intervention on X that will change Y when all other variables in V that are not on this path are fixed at some value. If there is only one path P from X to Y or if the only alternative path from X to Y besides P contains no intermediate variables (i.e., is direct), then X is a contributing cause of Y as long as there is some intervention on X that will change the value of Y, for some values of the other variables in V.

record.name: Duality of theorem and definition
record.description: Mendelson 1963 (third edition p.70, first edition p.83): "The topological concepts that have been studied [in the context of metric spaces] must be reintroduced in the context of topological spaces. The procedure for formulating the appropriate definitions of these terms in a topological space is to find, in a metric space, the characterization of the term by means of open sets, using in most cases what is a theorem in a metric space as a definition in a topological space."

record.name: Dual proposal: success pattern and constancy mechanism
record.description: The success pattern condition and the constancy mechanism condition are individually necessary and jointly sufficient for minimal intentionality.

record.name: Representations belong in a hierarchy of increasing complexity
record.description: This seems to be an uncontroversial claim.

record.name: The success pattern condition is a sufficient condition on minimal intentionality
Explanatory role criterion
record.description:
de Souza Filho 2022:5: For a state to be considered representational, "There should be something that the intentional explanation [i.e. an explanation which affords representational status to the state] is capable of explaining which the non-intentional explanation cannot explain."


de Souza Filho 2022 appears to treat the criterion as a necessary and sufficient condition on intentionality.

record.name: Extended active inference describes the causal reciprocal relationship between an individual organism and its cognitive niche
Minimizing free energy is a necessary condition on life
record.description:
Minimizing free energy in the past is a necessary condition on being alive now.


Constant 2021:1: "if you exist, now, under the right conditions, it is because you’ve done something like minimising your free energy."

record.name: Minimizing free energy is sufficient for life
record.description: [Created to enable Constant 2021 argument against]

record.name: Minimizing expected free energy requires sophisticated capacities for counterfactual reasoning
record.description: Kiverstein & Sims 2021 attribute this view to Corcoran et al 2020. I skimmed the latter and didn't find it.

record.name: Cognitive agents are those that perform counterfactual active inference
FEP models exacerbate a trade-off between generality and biological plausibility
Assumptions such as ergoditicity and NESS are implausible of biological systems
record.description:
Ergodicity: "However, the application of the ergodic theorem [of Birkhoff 1931] to real systems, whether in physics or biology, presents several challenges (Earman and Rédei 1996), and there are good reasons to think that this theorem cannot realistically be applied in the domain of biology."


(NB they don't seem to use the term NESS in the manuscript itself. It's possible that "random dynamical attractors" is supposed to be a synonym.)

record.name: Neurons are not relays
record.description: Planer & Godfrey-Smith 2021:760: "Neurons do not just propagate activity from one place to another; they create new patterns and activity. They do this both in ways that admit information-processing description (inference, filtering) and ways that may not."

record.name: Signals bear different involvement relations with world affairs
record.description: Planer & Godfrey-Smith 2021:763: There are various different involvement relations a sign can have to the world: "This is not a problem that needs to be solved by choosing one kind of involvement between sign and world and saying it is the basis of content. Instead, various kinds of sign-world relationship can be recognized."

record.name: Incrementalism about the origin of natural language
Simple Coordination Thesis
record.description:
Three parts:

  1. Our interpretative concepts constitute something like a theory of human cognitive organization: they are a putative description of the wiring-and-connection facts
  2. Our interpretative skills depend on this theory, and our ability to deploy it on particular occasions
  3. We are often able to successfully explain or anticipate behaviour because this theory is largely true.
